metadata.description: Zambian Bemba (IchiBemba) as spoken in Northern/Copperbelt regions

examples: A person is coming - Umuntu aleisa
person.culturalContext: Fundamental concept in Bemba philosophy of ubuntu (humanity)

examples: I want to tell you - Ndefwaya ukukweba
Tell them the truth - Bebe icishinka
tell.culturalContext: Verbal communication is important in Bemba culture for passing down knowledge and traditions

examples: The leopard is hunting - Imbwili ilelunga
I saw a leopard in the forest - Nalimwene imbwili mu mpanga
leopard.culturalContext: Highly respected predator in Bemba culture, often featured in proverbs and folklore. Also known as 'inswe' in some regions.

examples: He is annoyed with me - Namufulwisha
annoyed.culturalContext: Expression of displeasure in social interactions

examples: His matriculation ceremony is tomorrow - Ukwingila nelyo ukupwisha isukulu kwakwe ni mailo
After matriculation, he will look for a job - Panuma ya ukwingila nelyo ukupwisha isukulu, akafwaya incito
matriculation.culturalContext: Educational milestone celebrated in modern Bemba society

examples: They had a long dialog - Balikwete ukulanshanya ukutali
Let's have a dialog about it - Natukwate ukulanshanya pali ici
dialog.culturalContext: Conversation or discussion between people, important for conflict resolution and community decision-making in Bemba culture

examples: Thank you very much - Natotela sana
The food is ready - Ifyakulya fyapya
How are you this morning - Mwashibuka shani
how are you.culturalContext: Standard greeting in Bemba culture. 'Muli shani' is formal, while 'Uli shani' is informal.

examples: I am fine, thank you - Ndi bwino, natotela

uncle.culturalContext: Used to refer to one's uncle, showing respect

please.culturalContext: Shows politeness and respect when making requests

examples: No, I don't want - Awe, nshilefwaya
no.culturalContext: Negative response, often softened with politeness

examples: Welcome to our home - Mwaiseni kumwesu
The kiwano fruit is ripe - Mankangala nalipya
I like kiwano fruit - Nalitemwa mankangala
kiwano fruit.culturalContext: Kiwano, also known as the African horned cucumber or jelly melon, is a tropical fruit with a distinctive, spiky exterior. It has a bright orange rind when ripe and a lime-green, jelly-like flesh inside. The flavor is often described as a mix of cucumber, zucchini, and kiwi.

house.culturalContext: Center of family life in Bemba culture

examples: I want to eat - Ndefwaya ukulya
to eat.culturalContext: Eating together is an important social activity

examples: I want to drink water - Ndefwaya ukunwa amenshi
Drink this medicine - Nwa uyu umuti
I want to sleep - Ndefwaya ukulala
The baby is sleeping - Akanya nakalala
to sleep.culturalContext: Rest is important in Bemba culture

examples: I like to walk - Nalitemwa ukwenda
The children are running - Abana balekonkobela
to run.culturalContext: Often used in play and sports

examples: I want to speak Bemba - Ndefwaya ukulanda iciBemba
to speak.culturalContext: Oral communication is important in Bemba culture

to listen.culturalContext: Listening is a sign of respect in Bemba culture

examples: What is your name? - Ishina lyenu nimwe bani?
What is his name? - Ishina lyakwe nani?
My name is John - Ishina lyandi nine John
My name is Mary - Ishina lyandi nine Mary
The sun is hot - Akasuba nakaba
sun.culturalContext: Important in marking time and daily activities

moon.culturalContext: Traditional calendar is based on lunar cycles

star.culturalContext: Used in traditional navigation and storytelling

rain.culturalContext: Essential for agriculture and daily life

examples: The fire is hot - Umulilo nakaba
fire.culturalContext: Central to cooking and community gatherings

stone.culturalContext: Used in traditional tools and construction

book.culturalContext: Important for education and knowledge sharing

examples: Write with a pen - Lemba ne peni

penis.culturalContext: Anatomical term used in health education

examples: Go to school - Ya ku sukulu
The school is far - Isukulu lili ukutali
School teacher - Kafundisha wa ku sukulu
University student - Umusambi wa ku yunivesiti
student.culturalContext: Education is highly valued in Bemba culture

examples: The doctor is coming - Dokota aleisa
Go to hospital - Kabiye ku cipatala
The hospital is far - Icipatala cili kutali
Go to market - Ya ku masoko
The market is busy - Amasoko nayesula
market.culturalContext: Center of trade and community interaction

examples: The shop is closed - Icitolo nacisala

sister.culturalContext: Important family relationship with specific terms based on speaker's gender

child.culturalContext: Children are highly valued in Bemba society

examples: The baby is crying - Akanya kalelila
baby.culturalContext: Babies receive special care and attention in community

examples: The man is working - Umwaume alebomba
man.culturalContext: Traditional role as provider and protector

examples: The woman is cooking - Umwanakashi alepika
woman.culturalContext: Respected role in family and community

examples: The boy is playing - Umulumendo aleangala
boy.culturalContext: Young male, not yet an adult

bread.culturalContext: Common food item in modern Bemba diet

examples: The girl is singing - Umukashana aleimba
girl.culturalContext: Has specific cultural roles and initiations

examples: Can you see? - Bushe kuti wamona?
to see.culturalContext: Visual perception is important in learning and understanding

to play.culturalContext: Important for children's development and social bonding

good.culturalContext: Describes positive qualities in people and things

big.culturalContext: Size can indicate importance or status

small.culturalContext: Not necessarily negative, can show endearment

tall.culturalContext: Used for height and length measurements

short.culturalContext: Not considered disrespectful when describing height

fat.culturalContext: Can be a sign of prosperity in traditional context

thin.culturalContext: May indicate concern about health or resources

new.culturalContext: Often associated with progress and development

old.culturalContext: Can indicate wisdom when referring to people

beautiful.culturalContext: Describes both physical and inner beauty

ugly.culturalContext: More commonly used for behavior than appearance

clean.culturalContext: Cleanliness is highly valued in Bemba culture

dirty.culturalContext: Associated with poor hygiene and neglect

hot.culturalContext: Important for food preparation and weather

cold.culturalContext: Can refer to both temperature and illness

hard.culturalContext: Can describe physical or metaphorical hardness

soft.culturalContext: Often used for food and materials

heavy.culturalContext: Used for physical and metaphorical weight

light.culturalContext: Can refer to weight or difficulty level

slow.culturalContext: Not always negative, can mean careful or thorough

weak.culturalContext: Can indicate illness or lack of strength

rich.culturalContext: Wealth often associated with community responsibility

poor.culturalContext: Community expected to help those in need

examples: I am sad - Ndi no bulanda
In the afternoon - Mukati ka kasuba
afternoon.culturalContext: Time for main meal and rest in hot weather

evening.culturalContext: Time for family gathering and evening activities

night.culturalContext: Traditional time for storytelling and rest

examples: It's sunny today - Ilelo akasuba nakaba
sunny.culturalContext: Common weather condition affecting daily activities

rainy.culturalContext: Important for agriculture and daily planning

windy.culturalContext: Can affect daily activities and travel

head.culturalContext: Considered important part of body in traditional medicine

eye.culturalContext: Important for traditional beliefs and expressions

examples: Listen with your ears - Umfwa na matwi

nshima.culturalContext: Traditional staple food made from maize meal

examples: White clothes - Ifya kufwala fya ukubuta
Orange sunset - Akasuba kalepona aka orange
Navy blue car - Imotoka ya makumbi-ukufita
Indigo dye - Umuti wa kupenta wa makumbi-purple

lion.culturalContext: Symbol of strength in Bemba culture

elephant.culturalContext: Respected wild animal in traditional stories

examples: Group of baboons - Umukuni wa bakolwe
Striped tiger - Inkalamo ya mishishi ya mitundu
Big tiger - Inkalamo ya mishishi ikalamba
tiger.culturalContext: Not native to Africa but known through stories

examples: Spotted jaguar - Ingwe ya America ya matoni
Strong jaguar - Ingwe ya America iyakosa
jaguar.culturalContext: Foreign wild cat known through media

examples: Mountain puma - Ingwe ya brown ya mpili
Hunting puma - Ingwe ya brown ilelunga
Tree colobus - Nkwale wa mu cimuti
colobus monkey.culturalContext: Known for its distinctive black and white fur

examples: Colorful mandrill - Kolwe wa mishishi wa mibele
Male mandrill - Kolwe wa mishishi ilume

hyena.culturalContext: Featured in many traditional stories as a trickster

examples: Pack of wild dogs - Umukuni wa bambulu
Herd of antelopes - Umukuni wa nsasha

gazelle.culturalContext: Known for its grace and speed

examples: Group of impalas - Umukuni wa nswala

snake.culturalContext: Respected and feared in traditional beliefs

praying mantis.culturalContext: Named for its posture resembling prayer

examples: The fly landed on the food - Lunshi naikala pa fyakulya
housefly.culturalContext: Common pest associated with unsanitary conditions

examples: The tick is attached to the dog - Konto apapa pa mbwa

sunrise.culturalContext: Important time marker in daily village life

examples: The sun is setting - Akasuba kalepona
sunset.culturalContext: Traditional time to end daily work

How are you young man? - Uli shani mulumendo?
Good morning, how are you young man? - Mwashibukeni, uli shani mulumendo?
how are you young man.culturalContext: Respectful greeting to a young male, showing acknowledgment of their youth status
how are you young man.usage: Common greeting phrase used when addressing a young man or boy

examples: How are you young girl? - Uli shani mukashana?
Good morning, how are you young girl? - Mwashibukeni, uli shani mukashana?
how are you young girl.culturalContext: Respectful greeting to a young female, showing acknowledgment of their youth status
how are you young girl.usage: Common greeting phrase used when addressing a young girl or female child

where can I find mango trees.translation: ni kwisa ninga sanga ifimuti fya mango
where can I find mango trees.pronunciation: ni kwi-sa ni-nga sa-nga i-fi-mu-ti fya ma-ngo
examples: Where can I find mango trees? - Ni kwisa ninga sanga ifimuti fya mango?
I want to know where I can find mango trees - Ndefwaya ukwishiba ni kwisa ninga sanga ifimuti fya mango
synonyms: ni kwisa kwaba ifimuti fya mango
where can I find mango trees.culturalContext: Mangoes are popular fruits in Zambia, though not native to the region. They were introduced during colonial times and are now widely grown.
where can I find mango trees.usage: Useful phrase when looking for specific fruit trees or resources in a new area

examples: I exercise daily - Ndaibukisha cila bushiku
Daily tasks - Imilimo ya cila bushiku
daily.culturalContext: Used to describe regular activities that occur each day

damage.culturalContext: Refers to causing harm or destruction to property or objects

examples: The car is damaged - Imotoka naonauka
damaged.culturalContext: Describes items that have been harmed or broken

examples: The ground is damp - Mushili nabomba
damp.culturalContext: Describes slight wetness, often from moisture in the air

examples: The dampness in the house - Umutonshi mu ng'anda
There is dampness in the air - Kwaba umutonshi mu mwela
dampness.culturalContext: Refers to the quality of being slightly wet, especially in humid conditions

examples: She likes to dance - Alitemwa ukucila
dance.culturalContext: Important part of traditional ceremonies and celebrations

examples: Treatment for dandruff - Umuti wa nkuku

danger.culturalContext: Used to warn others about potential harm

dare.culturalContext: Act of challenging someone or taking a risk

dark.culturalContext: Absence of light or deep in color

examples: Walking in darkness - Ukwenda mu mfifi
darkness.culturalContext: Traditional time for rest and certain rituals

examples: What's the date today? - Bushiku nshi ileelo?
The meeting date - Ubushiku bwa kulongana

daughter.culturalContext: Important family relationship with specific roles

examples: She is a good daughter-in-law - Ni mupongoshi musuma
daughter-in-law.culturalContext: Important family relationship with specific traditional responsibilities

examples: Waking up at dawn - Ukubuka pa macca
dawn.culturalContext: Beginning of the day, traditionally when agricultural work begins

day.culturalContext: Basic unit of time, traditionally marked from sunrise to sunset

examples: The roosters crow at daybreak - Inkoko shilabeleela pa macca
daybreak.culturalContext: Important time marker in rural communities

daylight.culturalContext: Natural light during the day, important for activities

examples: The plant is dead - Icimuti naifwa
dead.culturalContext: Treated with great reverence in traditional beliefs

examples: A deaf person - Umuntu uwakoma matwi
deaf.culturalContext: Described in functional terms rather than as an identity

deafen.culturalContext: Refers to causing temporary or permanent hearing loss

examples: It's a good deal - Ciplo cisuma

dear.culturalContext: Term of endearment for loved ones

examples: The car is too dear - Imotoka yaliba koso mutengo

dear (expensive).culturalContext: Refers to high cost or price

examples: News of death - Ilyashi lya mfwa
death.culturalContext: Important transition in Bemba spirituality with specific rituals

examples: Join the debate - Isendamo mu kutlika
debate.culturalContext: Formal discussion or argument about a specific topic

examples: Don't call me a motherfucker - Wilangita tombanoko
motherfucker.culturalContext: Extremely offensive insult, not used in polite conversation

I cannot erase these memories - Teti mfute ifi fibukisho
Erect a pole here - Imika umwete pano
They erected a new building - Balimike icikulwa cipya
To err is human - Ukuluba kwaba muntunse
You erred in your calculation - Walilubile mu kulinga kobe
This is an error - Ici cilubo
Correct your errors - Lungika ifilubo fyobe
They escaped from danger - Balipusumwike ku busanso
Escort her home - Mushindike ku ng'anda
He escorted me to the bus stop - Alishindike ku citeshi ca basi
He exhorted them to work hard - Alibakonkomeshe ukubomba na maka
The pastor exhorted the congregation - Kakumanya akonkomeshe ulukuta
His exhortation was powerful - Ifunde lyakwe lyalikwete amaka
The exhortation moved many to tears - Ifunde lyasunkile abengi ku filamba
They exhumed the body for investigation - Balishukwile umubili ku kufwailisha
It is taboo to exhume bodies in some cultures - Mukati mu ntambi shimo, ukushukula imibili kwaliba icipyu
exhume.culturalContext: Culturally sensitive practice with specific rituals and taboos

examples: I expect you to come tomorrow - Ndekucetekela ukwisa mailo
They expect good results - Balecetekela ifisuma
His expectoration was bloody - Icikla cakwe calikwete umulopa
The doctor examined the expectoration - Shing'anga alilengele icikla
They expelled him from school - Balimutamfishe ku sukulu
The body expels toxins - Umubili ulatamfya ubusungu
This car is expensive - Iyi motoka yakoso mutengo
Education is becoming more expensive - Amasambililo yaleya yakoso mutengo
The scientists experiment with new medicines - Basayantisti balesha imiti ipya
Let's experiment with different methods - Natwesha inshila ishapusana
He is an expert in farming - Ni fundi mu bulimi
We need to consult an expert - Tufwile ukwipusha fundi
expert.culturalContext: Person with specialized knowledge or skill

examples: He tried to expiate his sins - Aeseshe ukuftila imembu shakwe
The sacrifice was to expiate their wrongdoing - Ilambo lyali ku kuftila ububifi bwabo
Please explain this concept - Nalomba londolola ici cishinka
The teacher explained the lesson well - Kafundisha alondolwele isambililo bwino
Don't let the pressure cooker explode - Wileleka ipoto ya mwela ilatule
They explored the forest - Balilengwile impanga
Let's explore different options - Natulengule inshila ishalekana lekana
Extend your hand - Tambalika ukuboko kobe
They extended the road - Balitambalike umusebo
The material is extensible - Icipaapa cilanyunsuluka
This rope is not extensible - Uyu mushilwa taunyunsuluka
The external part of the house - Icilundwa ca kunse ca ng'anda
External factors affected the decision - Ifintu fya kunse fyalicilingile ukusala
That animal species is extinct - Ubu bwana bwa nama balishima
The language is almost extinct - Ululimi luli mupepi no kushima
They extinguished all the candles - Balishimishe ifibuuto fyonse
They extolled his virtues - Balimulubanishe pa misango yakwe isuma
The poem extols the beauty of nature - Icakulembwa cilelumbanya ubusuma bwa calo
Extract the thorn from your foot - Bangula umonga mu lukasa lobe
She extracted the thorn carefully - Abangwile umonga na bucenjela
The dentist will extract the tooth - Shing'anga wa meno akanukula ilino
They had to extract his wisdom tooth - Balinukulile ilino lya mano
They extract copper from the ore - Balenga umukuba ukufuma mu cimabwe
The process to extract gold is complex - Inshila ya kwenga golide yalikalamba
It was an extraordinary performance - Cali cakucita ca ku kusungusha
She has extraordinary talent - Nakwata ukwishiba kwa ku kusungusha
He injured the extremity of his finger - Alicenele ulutwe lwa munwe wakwe
The extremities of the body get cold first - Ututwe twa mubili twalatalala intanshi
He has beautiful eyes - Alikwata amenso ayasuma
Look me in the eye - Ndelolekesha mu menso
She eyed him suspiciously - Amutontomeshe ne cilangoma
Don't eye other people's property - Wilatontomesha ifipe fya bantu bambi
She raised her eyebrows in surprise - Aimishe ifikumbi fyakwe mu kusungusha
His eyebrows are thick - Ifikumbi fyakwe fyalimbi
The old man has a cataract - Akalamba alikwata icibubi
Cataracts can be treated - Ifibubi kuti fyalundapwa
She has long eyelashes - Alikwata utukopyo utulepa
His eyelashes are very dark - Utukopyo twakwe twalifita sana
The famine affected many villages - Icipwe calengele imishi iingi
There was a severe famine last year - Kwali icipwe icikalamba umwaka wapita
famine.culturalContext: Historically significant during drought periods in Zambia

examples: He is a famous musician - Ni nyimbo walumbuka
The place became famous - Icifulo calibalumbwike
The village is far from here - Umushi uli kutali ukufuma pano
Don't go too far - Wiya kutali sana
Farewell my friend - Shalikapo we mune
He bid farewell to his family - Aebele ulupwa lwakwe ati shalikapo
farewell.culturalContext: Common farewell expression in Bemba culture

examples: He works on the farm - Abombela pa ibala
They have a large farm - Balikwata ibala ikulu
farm.culturalContext: Agricultural term important in Bemba society

examples: He is a hardworking farmer - Ni mulimi wabomba saana
The farmers are expecting rain - Abalimi balelolela imfula
farmer.culturalContext: Respected profession in traditional Bemba society

examples: The car is moving too fast - Imotoka ileenda lubilo sana
Fasten your seat belt - Ikasha lamba ya cipuna
He fastened the rope to the tree - Aikashishe umushilwa ku cimuti
Cook with less fat - Ipike na mafuta yanono
Animal fat is used in traditional medicine - Amafuta ya nama yabomfiwa mu miti ya cifyalilwa
The soup is too oily - Supu yanona sana
The meat is fatty - Inyama yanona
My father is coming - Tta aleisa
Father and son - Tta no mwana
father.culturalContext: Important familial term in Bemba culture

examples: He is a father of twins - Ni shimpundu
The father of twins received special recognition - Shimpundu apokelele umucinshi uwaibela
father of twins.culturalContext: Special status in Bemba culture, as twins are considered special

examples: My father in law visited yesterday - Pongoshi wandi aishile mailo
He respects his father in law - Acindika pongoshi wakwe
father in law.culturalContext: Important relation in Bemba marriage customs

examples: They fatten the cattle before selling - Balinya ing'ombe lintu tashalashitishiwa
Eating too much will fatten you - Ukulya sana kuti kwakwinya
The fault was in the engine - Icilubo cali mu njini
Please do me a favour - Napapata, njafwako
He asked for a favour - Alombele ukwafwa
This is my favourite food - Ici e cakulya candi kacele
She is his favourite child - Ni mwana wakwe kacele
He has fear of water - Alikwata umwenso wa menshi
They walked in fear - Baendele mu mwenso
He is a fearless warrior - Ni nkondo upama
The fearless hunter faced the lion - Kalwindi upama aiminina ku nkalamo
fearless.culturalContext: Valued trait in traditional warrior culture

examples: They prepared a feast for the visitors - Bapekanyishe amalila ku bakesa
The wedding feast was magnificent - Amalila ya bucuupo yali ayasuma
The bird has beautiful feathers - Icuni calikwata amasako ayasuma
He collected feathers for the ceremony - Alilongele amasako ku mulimo
feather.culturalContext: Used in traditional ceremonies and attire

examples: We will visit in February - Tukesa mu kabengele kakalamba
February is usually hot - Kabengele kakalamba ilingi libe ne cikabilila
The rain will fecundate the soil - Imfula ikimisha ishonde
The bull fecundated the cows - Ing'ombe ya cilume yaimishishe ing'ombe sha cikota
I am fed up with your excuses - Natendwa ne fyebe
They were fed up with waiting - Balitendwile ukulolela
The old man was feeble - Akalamba ali bonsa
Her voice was feeble due to illness - Ishiwi lyakwe lyali bonsa pa mulandu wa bulwele
The mother feeds her baby - Nyina alisha umwana
Can you feel the pain? - Bushe kuti waumfwa ubukali?
They fell the tree - Batemene icimuti
The lumberjacks fell trees for timber - Abatema ifimuti batema ifimuti ku mbao
He is a good fellow - Ni muntu musuma
He spoke about hell - Alelanda pa gehena
hell.culturalContext: Christian religious term, not traditional in Bemba cosmology
hell.usage: Religious term for place of punishment
